ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the methodology behind neighborhood effects and neighborhoods and crime. I really feel like I gained an excellent introduction to this field. I also feel more broadly that I have a gained a great deal of insight into different ways to think about social science more broadly.
How to be a better sociologist.
This class provides an in-depth overview of not only neighborhood literature but a survey of urban sociology

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: strength of the course was that it was a relaxed space, which made it amenable to "real life" conversations about how the material we were learning applied to the world around us. it made the class entertaining and feel useful. that said, a lot of the same (male) voices dominated the conversation.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Absolutely! excellent course with a great professor.
